The full trial design would be as follows: Participants will be randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to either the virtual tai chi easy intervention or usual care. The intervention will be virtual tai chi easy. Those assigned to usual care will receive the best care currently available at the site. Participants will complete the MGH Anxiety Quotient Assessment for adults and Medical outcomes study 8-Item Pain InterferenceScale at 8 weeks to evaluate pain and anxiety outcomes, as well as self-report opioid use. To date, there have been no previous clinical trials of Tai Chi aimed at substance use disorders. Research suggests Tai Chi may be an effective treatment for anxiety and chronic pain, and there is concern that incorporating mind-body practices may help address opioid use disorder. Thus, we hypothesize that virtual, online Tai Chi for Adults With Opioid Use Disorder (Tai Chi Easy) will have good outcomes related to anxiety and pain, and will reduce self-reported opioid use. Data collection will occur at baseline, 8 weeks, and 6 months, for a total of 2 years. There will be 10-12 participants per group.

groundtruth: In Phase 1 dose expansion cohorts, patients with Microsatellite Stable (MSS) CRC can have no more than 3 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. For H&N cancer, they can have no more than 2 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. For melanoma, they can have no more than 3 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, including at least 1 prior treatment with a BRAF inhibitor for patients with a BRAF mutation. For NSCLC, they can have no more than 2 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, including at least 1 prior treatment with a targeted therapy for patients with a mutation such as EGFR, ALK, KRAS, or RET. It's important to consider these criteria when enrolling patients in the dose expansion cohorts.

1. Experimental: Domiciliary CGA
   - Participant Group/Arm: Frail older adults over age 75 who are discharged from the Emergency Department and referred to the Community Specialist Team in Limerick.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention will consist of domiciliary Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment (CGA) including nursing, medical, and allied health assessment and intervention. The majority of this intervention will be delivered in the patient's own home, with a medical review at the hub for specialist geriatric medical expertise. A domiciliary visit within 24-48 hours of referral will be conducted by a team member who will act as the case coordinator. Referrals for domiciliary care will be made based on patient needs, with individualized interventions prescribed. This arm aims to assess the impact of providing CGA in a home-based setting, which may improve patient comfort, accessibility, and overall outcomes.

2. Active Comparator: Hub-based CGA
   - Participant Group/Arm: Frail older adults over age 75 who are discharged from the Emergency Department and referred to the Community Specialist Team in Limerick.
   - Intervention/Treatment: CGA as defined above will be delivered in an Out-patient setting at the hub. This arm serves as the comparison group to the experimental arm, allowing for the evaluation of the effectiveness of domiciliary CGA compared to hub-based CGA. It is necessary to have this arm to assess whether the setting of CGA delivery impacts clinical and process outcomes among older adults.

The other names for cemiplimab are REGN2810 and LIBTAYO. This arm is necessary to evaluate the safety and efficacy of cemiplimab as a monotherapy in treating microsatellite unstable localized or locally advanced colorectal cancer in older patients. By having a separate arm for cemiplimab alone, the researchers can assess its individual impact on the disease without any confounding factors from combination treatments. The second study arm is the experimental cohort B. The participant group/arm consists of patients who will receive both cemiplimab and fianlimab in combination. For this arm, patients will receive cemiplimab (350 mg administered IV) on Day 1 of each 21-day cycle for a total of 4 cycles of treatment. Additionally, they will also receive fianlimab (1600 mg administered IV) on Day 1 of each 21-day cycle for a total of 4 cycles of treatment. The other names for cemiplimab and fianlimab are REGN2810, LIBTAYO, and REGN3767 respectively. This arm is important to assess the safety and efficacy of the combination of cemiplimab and fianlimab in treating microsatellite unstable localized or locally advanced colorectal cancer in older patients. By including a combination arm, researchers can determine if the addition of fianlimab to cemiplimab provides any added benefit compared to cemiplimab alone. This arm allows for comparison between the two treatment approaches and provides valuable information on potential synergistic effects. What are your thoughts on this arm?

Good. For the intervention group, we will apply the blood flow restriction protocol. This is a noninvasive procedure that involves the use of inflatable cuffs on the lower limbs that restrict venous return to the heart and limit the amount of blood flowing back to the heart (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/243979843). There are two ways of applying an occlusion cuff; one is intermittent and the other continuous inflation. The intermittent form will have inflation and release of cuffs 5 sessions a week for 12 weeks. The continuous form requires one uninterrupted inflation till the end of the week. Thank you for providing all the necessary information. Based on the details you've shared, I would suggest designing a single study arm for your trial. This arm can be named "Experimental: finite arm." The participant group/arm would undergo the procedure of Zygomaticomaxillary fracture repair. We would start by using a cone beam CT scan to create a 3D scanned image of the Zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture. These 3D images will be introduced to finite element (FA) software to evaluate stresses, micromotion, and life time for each model. The analysis will help us determine the best point of fixation for the fracture. After applying this point of fixation on the patient, we would perform another round of finite element analysis to verify the results. This arm will provide valuable insights into the role of finite element analysis in selecting the optimal point of fixation for Zygomaticomaxillary complex fractures.

For the Vedolizumab arm, we'll include all patients with Crohn's Disease who could benefit from vedolizumab therapy. 5.6 Design and statistical considerations The selection of appropriate design for the proposed research study will depend on the type of research question being asked, for instance, should the research be an observational or an interventional study. A treatment vs control approach could be adopted where in the treatment group will receive an experimental treatment,  intervention or a new drug and the control group will receive the usual treatment, common practice, or drug. A crossover design can be used when the aim is to compare the two treatment groups. In case of a chronic illness like Crohn’s disease where the condition can be treated on and off and patient will experience periods of symptom-free and symptomatic state a within-subjects repeated measures design may be appropriate. In the within-subjects repeated measures design a participant is a subject for himself since he is measuring his/her responses at different time points. The following are the factors that can be varied: ❑ Treatment: Active treatment (Treatment of choice) & Placebo (or an alternate treatment) ❑ Time: Interval between 2 assessments within the same participant ❑ Dose (High dose & Low dose): This can be done by treating group & not in within subjects. For example in the treatment of ulcer disease, a patient may be treated with a high dose of antacid for a period before the measurement is taken, the measurement are compared to his usual response(s) ❑ Method of administration: Oral & rectal The selection aims to study the dose, time, and method of administration of a drug or treatment. 5.7 Ethical issues In the selection of an appropriate design for a research will depend on the research question and the nature of the research being undertaken. There are ethical concerns that needs to be addressed in all research especially a clinical trial. Clinical Trials are broadly classified into phase 1, 2, 3 and 4 and the ethical requirements differ. We propose to conduct a randomized clinical trial to test the efficacy of the Army Health mobile application in improving psychological resiliency and preventing suicidal ideation in National Guard and Reserve soldiers. The primary objective of the study is to test the efficacy of the Army Health app in reducing behavioral health problems and improving overall resiliency, as well as improving mental and physical health outcomes.
The study will run for a period of one year, with six months of pre-treatment baseline data collection followed by one year of treatment. A one-month washout period will also occur at study conclusion to enable participants to continue using the app if they wish. The study population will consist of 2,000 eligible participants (1,000 per arm). The target recruitment timeframe is 24 months.
After obtaining institutional and local IRB approval, a study flyer will be distributed to all personnel at a randomized centralized location, soliciting participants and providing study information. Eligible participants who express interest will be contacted by telephone to discuss study participation, answer questions about the study, and screen for exclusion/inclusion criteria.
Once all required forms (IRB, consent, etc.) are obtained, participants will be randomized to the intervention or control arm using a central secure web-based randomization system. Allocation concealment will occur at the centralized, investigational drug supply center, and participants will receive an alert notification upon randomization.
Intervention/Treatment:
The intervention is the Army Health mobile application, which will be made available to participants after randomization, and includes a range of tools, including health tracking, skill-building exercises, mood monitoring, and connectivity with a healthcare professional or coach. Participants in the behavioral intervention group will have the option to download the app via their existing government-issued smart phone or tablet, and all information entered in the app is encrypted and anonymous. Intervention Details:
- Ziv-Aflibercept is an investigational or experimental anti-cancer agent that inactivates vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) from functioning. It has been shown to prevent the formation of new blood vessels in tumors and inhibit tumor growth. Blocking VEGF may also enhance the immune response against cancer.
- Cemiplimab is a human monoclonal anti-PD-1 antibody that works by blocking the programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor on immune cells. This helps enhance the immune response against cancer cells.

Certainly! The full study design will be as follows: This is an open-label randomized controlled non-blinded study in Khatamullah hospital. Patients between 18 to 70 years of age, who are scheduled to undergo chemotherapy that may cause nausea and vomiting, will be screened for eligibility. Patients will be randomized to one of two treatment arms 3 days prior to the commencement of chemotherapeutic agents. The first treatment arm consists of ondansetron given every 3 days, in combination with aprepitant and dexamethasone given on the morning of the first day of chemotherapy. The second treatment arm consists of ondansetron given every week, in combination with aprepitant and dexamethasone at bedtime on the night before the first day of chemotherapy. Treatment will continue for 5 days each cycle of chemotherapy (on the first day of chemotherapy to the fourth day after chemotherapy). The Primary end-point is complete control of the emesis. Other endpoints include time to first emetic episode, numbers of emetic episodes, responder analysis (yes/no response), change in body weight, incidence of adverse effects and the cost-effectiveness of the two arms.

We came up with this idea because there is a shortage of Registered Dietitian Nutritionists (RDNs) in the community who are available to help older adults who are at risk of malnutrition. This study aims to examine whether a stepped-wedge cluster randomized controlled trial design is a useful way to test the effectiveness of our new model of community nutrition care after hospital discharge. In this study model, all participants will receive nutrition care at the same time, rather than randomizing them to different treatments. We expect that this model will be more efficient and cost-effective than other study designs, while still providing the necessary high quality research evidence to determine if our model is effective in improving patient outcomes and reducing healthcare costs.

groundtruth:
Certainly! This study arm is essential as it is the main intervention being tested in the trial. Providing nutrition care by RDNs and medical nutrition therapy to patients who are at risk for malnutrition and food insecurity is crucial in improving their food security, quality of life, and health outcomes. The stepped wedge cluster-randomized trial design allows for all participants to receive the intervention, ensuring that all individuals have the opportunity to benefit from the treatment.

By including this study arm, we can assess the impact of nutrition care and meals provided by RDNs on program sustainability, referrals, food insecurity, malnutrition risk and diagnosis, and quality of life. It will generate level 1 evidence and contribute to the development of a new model for nutrition care that may improve food security, quality of life, and health outcomes.

For the control group, we can label the participant group/arm as "Control: Standard treatment". The control group will receive standard care, which includes intravenous thrombolysis and supportive therapy, but without additional injections of Ghrelin. This group will serve as the benchmark against which the effects of Ghrelin in the experimental group can be compared.
The intervention/treatment for the control group will be no Ghrelin administration.

The control group is required to establish the efficacy of the experimental intervention. Without a control group, we cannot determine whether the observed results in the experimental group are due to the intervention or other factors. In this case, we are comparing the effect of Ghrelin against usual care.

Title P2: Study Design for Diagnostic and Therapeutic Implications
Introduction Urine flow rate could be used to predict patients who are most likely to benefit from a certain treatment option for lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). A prospective study is needed to demonstrate the usefulness of urine flow rate measurement as a screening tool for predicting response to treatment. Therefore, the following hypothesis is being tested:
H0: In patients with LUTS and anuria, urine flow rate in the voiding phase of the urine flow meter will not be associated with patient symptoms as measured by the IPSS.
H1: In patients with LUTS, urine flow rate in the voiding phase of the urine flow meter will be associated with patient symptoms as measured by the IPSS.
Study population Patients with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) from either benign prostatic hyperplasia, overactive bladder, or chronic prostatitis / chronic pelvic pain syndrome
Control strategy This is a longitudinal cohort/observational study. Urine flow rate and IPSS will be assessed at baseline and at one month follow-up.
Timing Study visits will be at 8-week intervals. Patients who demonstrate an increase in urine flow rate of greater than 0.5 mL/sec from baseline to follow-up will be followed for another 8 weeks.
Outcome measures 1. Urine flow rate in the voiding phase (1st 30 seconds) of urine flow meter 2. International prostate symptom score (IPSS)
Brief description of the study study population and intervention (detailed further below) study endpoint(s)/outcome(s). study period: timings and duration.
Sample size Determine number of patients required by power analysis. A two-sample t test, assuming a pooled standard deviation of urine flow rate (SD = 200 mL/sec)

The first arm will be the active comparator for the adaptive phenotypes, where participants will receive the study drug. The second arm will be the experimental group for the maladaptive phenotypes, also receiving the study drug. The third arm will be the placebo comparator for the adaptive phenotypes, and the fourth arm will be the placebo comparator for the maladaptive phenotypes. Does this sound good to you?

Certainly! Let's start with the active comparator for the adaptive phenotypes. This group will consist of the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups. Participants will be administered Dupilumab (Dupixent), an interleukin-4 receptor alpha antagonist. They will also be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The goal is to evaluate the efficacy of Dupilumab in individuals with adaptive phenotypes.

The experimental group for maladaptive phenotypes will also be divided into Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. Participants in this group will receive Dupilumab (Dupixent) and undergo exposure to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The purpose is to assess the effectiveness of Dupilumab in individuals with maladaptive phenotypes and compare the treatment response between adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes.

The placebo comparator arms will mirror the adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes. Participants in the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups will receive an inert placebo instead of the active drug but will still be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The same applies to the Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. These arms are important for establishing a baseline response in adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes when not receiving the active drug.

2. Experimental: Maladaptive Phenotypes randomized to study drug
   - Participant Group/Arm: Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroup
   - Intervention/Treatment: Dupilumab (Dupixent) and exposure to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber.

3. Placebo Comparator: Adaptive Phenotype randomized to placebo
   - Participant Group/Arm: Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroup
   - Intervention/Treatment: Inert placebo and exposure to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber.

   - Participant Group/Arm: Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroup
   - Intervention/Treatment: Inert placebo and exposure to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber.

model_response: Yes, there are several outcome measures. First, we will evaluate the complete pathological response rate, which is assessed by surgical sampling of tumors after neoadjuvant therapy. Second, we will measure the duration of response, which is defined as the time from the start of treatment to disease progression or death from any cause. Third, we will evaluate adverse events and adverse event-free survival. Fourth, we will evaluate the proportion of participants who experience a treatment-related serious adverse event. Fifth, we will measure progression-free survival, which is defined as the time from the start of treatment to progression or death from any cause. Sixth, we will evaluate overall survival, which is defined as the time from the start of treatment to death from any cause. Seventh, we will measure time to treatment failure, which is defined as the time from the start of treatment to failure of the neoadjuvant therapy regime. And finally, we will measure adverse event-free survival during the follow-up period.

model_response: Yes, this design was based on the findings of our formative research. During our formative research, we found that participants were resistant to behavioral interventions, especially those who were skeptical about behavioral interventions, such as female sex workers. It was also based on our experience from similar studies where participants were not ready to adopt new behaviors after short-term behavioral interventions.  We were also concerned that if we did not provide a clear comparison group, it would be difficult to prove the impact of the behavioral intervention. Therefore, we decided to have a comparison arm that received a minimal didactic intervention to ensure a comparison group. We feel that providing access to test kits every three months will have a positive impact on testing behavior and will not overwhelm participants with excessive information.
Excellent! Let's move on to the objectives. 😊 What are the study objectives for this clinical trial?
groundtruth: Absolutely! The design of the study arms is well-thought-out and tailored to the specific population of female sex workers who inject drugs in Kazakhstan. The AEGIDA intervention arm aims to assess the effectiveness of a comprehensive behavioral intervention in increasing HIV testing and linkage to care among the target population. By focusing on key factors such as peer education, stigma coping, and self-testing, this arm aims to address barriers to testing and promote positive health behaviors among participants. On the other hand, the AEGIDA control arm serves as a standard of care and provides basic information on self-screening and testing. It ensures that all participants have equal opportunities for testing throughout the study period.

   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes participants who will receive the AEGIDA intervention, which is a 4-session behavioral intervention aimed at promoting consistent HIV testing, frequent testing, and intention to uptake PEP/PrEP.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention arm involves one-on-one sessions facilitated by trained staff, focusing on various aspects such as HIV self-testing, peer education, stigma coping and resistance, and provision of HIV self-test kits. The sessions are designed to address the unique needs and challenges faced by female sex workers who inject drugs, including issues related to stigma, empowerment, and harm reduction. Providing access to HIV self-test kits every three months is also a crucial component of this arm.

2. Active Comparator: AEGIDA control arm

From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly active tDCS sessions preceding the scheduled yoga sessions. In the Sham Comparator: Sham tDCS arm, participants will attend five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of sham transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly sham tDCS sessions before the scheduled yoga sessions. The sham tDCS sessions will mimic the sensation of current without actual stimulation. Participants will also participate in the same yoga program led by a certified instructor.

model_response:
Observational study phases may vary, but here's a general definition from the FDA: Phase 0 - the drug first meets preclinical testing standards and the safety and dosage of the drug are tested in a small number of healthy patients or a small number of patients with the disease of interest. Phase I - the drug is tested in a small group of healthy volunteers to determine safety, dosage, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and adverse effects. Phase II - the drug is tested on individuals with the disease of interest to confirm its safety, effectiveness, and dosage. Phase III - the drug is tested on an expanded group of patients with the disease of interest, in a controlled comparison with a placebo and under double blind conditions (neither the patient nor the doctor knows whether the patient is getting the drug or a placebo). Phase 4 - post marketing trials or surveillance studies in large numbers of people to study long-term effects and any side effects of the medicine.

The flowchart below summarizes the treatment and diagnostic protocol for the case of Microscopic Colitis. The first step is the identification of the potential participants in the community based on the prevalence statistics and the description of the case definition. The third step is optional in some cases depending on the clinical suspicion. The fourth step is the analysis of the biopsies to confirm the diagnosis. For the pulmonary vein isolation, a catheter ablation technique will be used to create electrical isolation around the pulmonary veins, preventing pulmonary vein ectopy from triggering atrial fibrillation. This is a crucial step in comparing the efficacy of ablation versus cardioversion in reducing AF recurrence. As for the DC cardioversion, it will be performed if the patient is still in AF at the end of the pulmonary vein isolation procedure. The implantable loop recorder, known as the Reveal device, will be inserted in the pre-pectoral position under the skin with local anesthetic and sedation at least a week before randomization. It will provide continuous recording of the heart rhythm and rate, which can be downloaded via a home monitoring system to establish the primary endpoint of the study. Lastly, two femoral sheaths (7Fr) will be inserted using ultrasound guidance under local anesthetic. These sheaths will serve as the access route for cardiac catheter insertion during the procedure. It will provide continuous recording of the heart rhythm and rate for data collection. Two femoral sheaths (7Fr) will also be inserted using ultrasound guidance under local anesthetic. In addition, a sham procedure will be performed after randomization, along with intermittent phrenic nerve pacing. This sham procedure, along with the use of intermittent phrenic nerve pacing, serves as a control group to compare the outcomes of the active intervention arm and assess the specific impact of pulmonary vein isolation in reducing AF recurrence. model_response: The control arm is necessary to ensure that any differences we observe between the two arms are attributable to the intervention and not other factors. For example, if we only observe a difference in postoperative complications between the two arms, but the difference persists even after accounting for other factors such as age, severity of disease, or preoperative inflammatory markers, we would know that these factors do not explain the difference. In that case, we could be more confident that the difference is due to the intervention.

Comparing the outcomes of the control arm to the experimental arm will provide valuable insights into the potential benefits of Zinc supplementation.

Let's review the inclusion and exclusion criteria from the previous example with some additional explanations. We can see that inclusion criteria 1, 2, and 3 are the same. However, we did state that the first criterion was altered to include burns received within the last 7 days. The reason for this is to ensure that the burns do not get older and the wounds start to heal. By having an inclusion period of only 7 days, it will restrict the study to new burns only.
The exclusion criteria were also altered. Exclusion criterion 4 was changed from no history of renal or liver disease to no recent surgery in the last 7 days. Because surgery in the last 7 days can cause a change in renal or liver function, it was decided to exclude any patient who has had surgery in the last 7 days. Exclusion criterion 5 was changed from no history of metabolic disease to no history of psychiatric disease. Psychiatric disease may alter hemodynamics and thus, affect the readings taken while the patient is undergoing fluid resuscitation. By excluding patients with a history of psychiatric disease, it ensures a baseline measure of hemodynamics can be taken prior to fluid resuscitation.

   - Participant Group/Arm: Seventeen patients who have been diagnosed by an Ear, Nose, and Throat specialist as having a risk of obstructive sleep apnea and showing pharyngeal muscle collapse in the velopharyngeal area/retropalatal.
   - Intervention/Treatment: These participants will perform myofunctional therapy exercises two times per day for 20 minutes every day for six weeks. The exercises will target muscles in the soft palate, tongue, face, and pharynx. Compliance will be monitored through exercise logs, video submissions, and weekly evaluations by the doctor. groundtruth: For the second study arm, we can include a sham comparator group. This arm will help us control for placebo effects and ensure the validity of the study results. Participants in this arm will receive sham Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation. The electrode positions and stimulation parameters will be the same as the active tDCS arm, but the current will only be delivered for the initial 30 seconds. This arm will allow us to distinguish between the actual effects of tDCS and any placebo effects. This is crucial in establishing the true efficacy of tDCS in treating LLD. What are your thoughts on this?

Great! To summarize, we have two study arms: 
1. Experimental: Active tDCS
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes participants who will receive active Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation targeting the prefrontal cortex.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants in this arm will receive tDCS, which involves the delivery of a weak electrical current through scalp electrodes to modulate brain activity. This intervention aims to improve depressive symptoms in LLD patients who have not responded to traditional antidepressant therapy.
   - Reasoning: This arm is necessary to assess the efficacy of tDCS as an adjunctive treatment for LLD. By comparing the outcomes of participants receiving active tDCS to those receiving sham tDCS, we can determine the true effects of tDCS on depressive symptoms in this population.

2. Sham Comparator: Sham tDCS
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes participants who will receive sham Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Participants in this arm will undergo a sham tDCS procedure, where the electrode positions and stimulation parameters are the same as active tDCS, but the current is only delivered for the initial 30 seconds.
   - Reasoning: The inclusion of a sham comparator arm is essential to control for placebo effects and ensure the validity of the study results. By comparing the outcomes of participants receiving sham tDCS to those receiving active tDCS, we can determine if any observed effects are due to the actual stimulation or simply the placebo effect. This arm helps to establish the true efficacy of tDCS in treating LLD.

To design the allocation, you'll need to determine whether your patient population is small or large enough for randomization (to justify the time spent during the randomization process). If many patients are needed per group to fulfill your power calculations, but there are enough patients to conduct the trial at baseline, then you may want to proceed to Randomization. Allocation is usually performed by a central, independent party not involved with trial conduct. A computer software program like http://www.randox.com/specialized-software/minimize.html  or Minimize (designed by the same group that produced the CONSORT statement) may be used. In contrast, if you expect the number of eligible patients to be low, you will want to consider Alternate Allocation. Alternate allocation may also be done via a computer program to stratify by site, date, etc. If at study end there is no clear winner, then you can do a Cochrane-Moulton test or a responder-blind or "efficacy only"mask (http://clinical trials.aappublications.org/ctp/glance/monitoring.dtl) after all events have occurred. I hope this helps!

The second arm could be an active comparator called "Standard investigation". Similar to the first arm, this arm would include patients undergoing investigation for possible coronary heart disease in primary care. Clinical Study Design: Phase 1/1b Study of QL1706H in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors
Study Drug: QL1706H Drug Class: Oral and Injectable QL1706H
Objectives: The primary objective is to characterize the safety, maximum tolerated dose (MTD), pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of QL1706H in patients with advanced solid tumors. The secondary objectives are to evaluate anti-tumor activity of QL1706H in patients with advanced solid tumors and to evaluate the pharmacodynamics of QL1706H in patients with solid tumors.
Study design: This is a Phase 1/1b, multi-center, open-label study planned to be conducted in approximately 64 patients with advanced solid tumors.
Study Population: Males or females >/=18 years of age with measurable or evaluable solid tumors, who have been treated at least 4 weeks or 5 days after the last treatment with an investigational drug or device, and who have had disease progression after at least one lines of chemotherapy, including a PD-(L)1/EGFr antibody (at the discretion of the investigator) or recurrence following curative surgery.
Study Duration: Maximum of approximately 75 weeks.
Study Plan: Patients are initially assigned to escalating dose levels of QL1706H orally or intravenously once every 21 days in a 3 + 3 dose escalation design. Each dose level will consist of three patients for QL1706H intravenous dosing and six patients for QL1706H oral dosing. If three of six patients experience dose limiting toxicity at a dose level, that level will be considered the MTD. - Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD) group:
  - Participant Group/Arm: Subject with a history of SCAD will undergo a series of diagnostic studies to assess neurovascular function.
  - Intervention/Treatment:
    - Arterial Tonometry: Measure arterial stiffness using arterial tonometry.
    - Echocardiogram: Collect limited ultrasound images of the heart.
    - Carotid Ultrasounds: Perform ultrasound imaging of the carotid artery.
    - Elastography: Measure the elastic properties of the arteries using elastography.
    - Ankle-Brachial Index: Measure the ankle-brachial index to assess peripheral artery blood flow.
    - Microneurography with sympathoexcitatory maneuvers: Measure sympathetic nerve activity at rest and in response to isometric handgrip, mental stress test, cold pressor test, Valsalva maneuvers.

- Healthy Control Group:
  - Participant Group/Arm: Healthy subjects will undergo a series of diagnostic studies to assess neurovascular function.

    - Arterial Tonometry: Measure arterial stiffness using arterial tonometry.

Excellent! Our inclusion and exclusion criteria have been established. Let's move on to sample size estimation.
Sample size estimation is an important part of protocol development and an integral component of protocol review. Estimating the sample size for a clinical trial requires several factors, including the effect size, precision, alpha level, and beta error rate. Alpha and beta rates are critical because they determine the statistical power of the study. In general, the alpha level is usually set at 0.05, and the beta error rate is set at 0.20.
Once we have the alpha and beta errors established, we need to determine the power of the study. Power refers to the probability of detecting a treatment effect if it exists. For example, if the power is 0.80, it means that if the treatment does have an effect, we will detect it 80% of the time. How many participants we need to include in the study depends on what we are measuring and the precision of the measurements. A clinical trial may need to recruit several hundred or even a few thousand participants to be able to detect a treatment effect with sufficient precision.
How long it takes to reach a targeted sample size depends on the study design, the drug under study, and the effect size. In some cases, it may take several years to reach the sample size required. However, it's important to be honest about time requirements in clinical trial design to avoid delays and to make sure the study does not exceed the funds available or the participants' willingness to participate.
The sample size estimation is critical because it helps us determine whether the study is likely to be successful. Poorly designed studies can waste money, time, and resources, whereas well-designed studies save them. By carefully considering the sample size in the protocol planning stage, we can increase the chances of a successful clinical trial.

groundtruth: Great! Now that we have all the necessary information, let's start designing the study arms. Based on the details provided, we can create two study arms. The first arm is the experimental arm, named "Early supplementary." Participants in this group will receive supplementary parenteral nutrition starting on postoperative day 2. The intervention or treatment for this arm will be the drug SmofKabiven. The dosage will be adjusted daily based on the participant's calorie intake. This arm is important to assess the impact of early supplementary parenteral nutrition on postoperative outcomes and to evaluate if early intervention improves nutritional status and recovery compared to delayed administration.

The second arm is the active comparator arm, named "Late supplementary." Participants in this group will start receiving supplementary parenteral nutrition on postoperative day 5. Similar to the experimental arm, the intervention or treatment for this arm will also be the drug SmofKabiven. The dosage will be adjusted daily based on the participant's calorie intake. This arm serves as a comparison to the early supplementary group, allowing us to determine if delaying the start of parenteral nutrition until day 5 has any impact on outcomes. By having a delayed start group, we can evaluate the potential benefits of early intervention in the experimental arm.

Here's the protocol for each arm:  Rex Implants with Machined Transcortical Portion Experimental protocol:  - Gauge and length of the implant will be based on the CBI guidelines.  - 1.5 mm drilling: Drilling angle is 15 degrees to the long axis of the implant, and the depth of the incision is 5mm deep and 3 mm anterior to the bone crest.  - Bone Consumption Procedure:  - Bone drilling: A 2.0 mm tap is used to enlarge the tapering of the implant. This tapering should be done until the bone-implant interface is parallel with the long axis of the implant.  - Bone expansion: An expander will be used to increase the diameter of the prepared site with 0.5 mm increments until the flap reaches 70 degrees to the horizontal bone plate.  - 2.5 mm Heat sterilization: The implant is untapped from the handle and sterilized with a 2.5 mm tap. This is done to create a more stable insertion angle.  - 3.0 mm tap: The implant is tapped 3.0 mm to provide stability during screwinsertion. - Screw placement: The implant is inserted with 2.0 mm in the coronal direction and 4 mm sagittal to a stable region of the cortical bone away from the implant.  - Evaluation: 3-month and 12-month radiographs will be taken to assess bone response. The study will involve comparing bone consumption and expansion procedures on machined and roughed transcortical implants. The study design will randomly assign patients to receive one of the two types of implants for a given extraction site.  This study will be a multi-center, parallel group, double blind, randomized study with at least 100 participants per group (machined vs roughed transcortical). One investigator will assign subjects to the implants in a sequentially numbered, opaque, sealed envelope to minimize the risk of allocation bias. The study population will consist of patients with at least one partially edentulous mandibular mandible who are smokers. Patients with any concomitant extractions, those with any disease that may affect jaw bone healing, or any procedure in the re-implantation region will be excluded.

Cross-sectional cohort would be where you just select people at the beginning, and then you follow them for some time course, but they are not randomly assigned to different groups. model_response: A Phase 3 trial is a type of clinical trial that aims to confirm the safety and efficacy of a treatment under investigation. The treatment is then approved for general use by the regulatory agency in charge of approving drugs and treatments.    - Participant Group/Arm: Individuals with severe symptoms indicative of irreversible pulpitis in mature molar teeth.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Determining the working length, chemomechanical preparation using specific files, irrigation with NaOCl and EDTA, and filling the root canals with epoxy-resin-based sealer using lateral condensation technique.

model_response: Phase 1 is the first phase of clinical trials that tests a new treatment in a small group of healthy volunteers or people with the disease, to determine safe dosage levels and the drug's side effects. Phase 2 studies further test the treatment in a larger group of people with the disease to study its effectiveness and to evaluate the treatment's safety in more detail. Phase 3 is a large-scale test of the treatment in an even larger group of people, usually comparing it to the standard treatment, to verify its safety and effectiveness. Phase 4 is a long-term follow-up to the previous phases to see if the effects of the treatment last. I understand. Thank you for the detailed criteria. Now, let's move on to designing the study arms. Based on the information provided, I suggest the following arms:

1. Experimental: Group 1: Picture-based prevention education and an educational course
- Participant Group/Arm: This group will receive both picture-based prevention education and participate in an educational course.
- Intervention/Treatment: The participants will have access to picture-based prevention education, which can help them visually understand the importance of hand care and protection. Additionally, the educational course will provide them with more in-depth knowledge and skills on how to prevent hand eczema effectively.
- Reasoning: This study arm is reasonable as it allows for a comprehensive approach to educating and training the participants on hand eczema prevention. By combining both visual aids and a structured course, participants are more likely to retain and apply the information provided, leading to potentially better outcomes in terms of reducing the incidence and severity of hand eczema.

2. Experimental: Group 2: Picture-based prevention education only (no educational course)
- Participant Group/Arm: This group will only receive picture-based prevention education without participating in an educational course.
- Intervention/Treatment: The participants will have access to visual aids for understanding and preventing hand eczema but will not receive the additional training provided in the educational course.
- Reasoning: This study arm is necessary to evaluate the effectiveness of picture-based prevention education alone in preventing hand eczema. By isolating this intervention, researchers can determine its impact on the outcomes compared to the group that receives both visual education and a course. This arm helps to assess the specific contribution of visual aids in preventing hand eczema among hospital cleaners.

3. Placebo Comparator: Group 3: Placebo (control)
- Participant Group/Arm: This group will serve as the control group and will not receive any picture-based prevention education or educational course.
- Intervention/Treatment: The participants in this group will not have access to the interventions provided to the experimental groups.
- Reasoning: This study arm is essential to establish a baseline for comparison with the experimental groups. By having a control group that does not receive any intervention, researchers can determine the true impact of the picture-based prevention education and educational course on preventing hand eczema. This arm helps to control for any external factors that may influence the outcomes and allows for a more accurate assessment of the interventions' effectiveness.

The sample size required for the clinical trial depends on the effect size, which is represented by power, and the significance level, which is represented by alpha. A power of 80% and an alpha of 5% indicate that the study has 80% power to detect an effect if it is really there, and an effect is actually there 5% of the time by chance. The required sample size depends on too many factors to lay out here (for example, the effect size, the variance, and the correlation between observations). However, one simple formula used in clinical trials estimation is: Sample Size = Z2Xpq/2*[1-beta], where Z is the standard normal distribution with a given α/2, p is the frequency of the disease in the population, and q is the frequency of the disease in the control population, and β is 1-β. In the following example, let's assume we need to detect a difference of standard deviation units between the treatment and control groups, and two-thirds (2/3) of those affected by the disease will be included in the study. This sample size estimation formula is: Sample size = 2[1-(0.66)]=4.3*Z(0.025,2)=127.3. This number of subjects should be randomly selected and stratified 3:1 ratio in order to have 68.5% power to detect a treatment difference of 1-standard deviation unit size in the treatment vs. control groups. With these simple numbers, we could run into problems with large number of subjects needed if the population prevalence is too low. β=1-β=1-0.925=0.075, so we would need about 1273 subjects to have 80% power to detect a treatment effect if it is indeed there.

In many trials, participants are allocated to either the intervention of interest (experimental group) or a sham or "control" procedure (usually placement in the supine rather than prone position) or receive a placebo. This is referred to as a "sham." Inert substances, such as sugared solution or a saline injection, are sometimes used to keep the treatment team and participant blinded to the intervention. Particularly in high-risk populations such as critically ill surgical participants or those with acute strokes, ensuring blinding may be difficult, but can help protect the study integrity.

The consent form provided to the subject is to be signed and dated by the study participant before the initiation of the study. The sponsor (independent or otherwise) will maintain a signed consent form for a minimum of three years past the study conclusion. 8 Recruitment 8.1 Recruitment Strategies Participant recruitment is one of the most challenging tasks of conducting a study. Recruitment will vary depending on the population of interest, the type of study design, and the type of study site (e.g., clinic, school). For some studies, social media recruitment may also be an option. When devising a recruitment strategy, consider the following: Will there be a need for screening of potential participants? Will there be a screening instrument? What types of participants will be eligible and ineligible? Who can participate (e.g., any patient with a specific diagnosis or only those diagnosed within a specific timeframe)? What locations (e.g., only a specific clinic or research site, or can participants be recruited at home) should be targeted? What methods of recruitment will be used (e.g., posting flyers, mailing, advertisements, social media)? To what populations will the announcement be directed (e.g., patients only, community residents, employees of a particular organization)? How many participants should be enrolled? How will participants be retained? What monitoring mechanisms will be in place to track the flow of participants through different stages of the study? Recruitment of study participants typically begins at the planning stage of the study, not after IRB review. In some cases, a recruitment plan may have to be modified during the study due to lower than expected or higher than anticipated enrollment numbers.
8.2 Recruitment Procedures The following procedures are suggested for participants who agree to be contacted about study opportunities: Initial Contact All recruitment contacts should begin with the establishment of contact information for the prospective participant (including address, telephone and e-mail addresses). A written or verbal description of the research study should then be provided. The purpose of the research should be explained and a voluntary participation request should be made. Consent should never be oral—consent forms must be signed and dated before any study-related procedures occur, including provision of information about the research.
